channel.title: Year 11 English: Othello VS O, Text and context
channel.description:
ok, i have a major exam in 33 hours that i have done almost no study for, hell, i have never even read the book "othello", although i was present when it was being studied in class, and i did study alot of it, so i grasp all the basic concepts being brought across: -othello is a black man in white mans society -othello only attained his present position because of military superiority -venetians viewed othello as being primal and "below" them in a sense. -the thinly shrouded veil of othello's equality with the venetians is ripped away when he marries desdamona. -othello is too trusting of others -Othello descends into madness from iago's baiting
and i also have watched the movie O plenty of times: -odin is a black kid at an all white school -odin only attained his present position because of his sporting prowess -white people view othello as being "different" -the dean gets pissed at odin for gettin wiv his daughta(sorry for this line, but i cant think of any other way of putting it. in contrast to othello, the rest of the community still accepts him) -odin trusts hugo too much -odin descends into madness from hugo's baiting. the cocaine doesnt help either.
basically, what im after is as much information as possible that someone can give me about the relationships between the 2 texts when it comes to "text and context" im really after a band 6(i think its the equivalent of a GPA of 4.0) which is basically the highest mark possible. according to the board of studies website, to attain a band 6, one must: [code] · displays a highly developed ability to describe and analyse a broad range of language forms, features and structures of texts and explain the ways these shape meaning and influence responses in a variety of texts and contexts. · presents a critical, refined personal response showing highly developed skills in interpretation, analysis, synthesis and evaluation of texts and textual detail. · exhibits an ability to compose imaginatively, interpretively and critically with sustained precision, flair, originality and sophistication for a variety of audiences, purposes and contexts in order to explore and communicate ideas, information and values. [/code]
http://www.boardofstudies.nsw.edu.au/syllabus_hsc/pdf_doc/english_syl.pdf around page 45 is the stuff i gotta worry about. im advanced english.

item.title: Year 11 English: Othello VS O, Text and context
item.dc:creator: @elementalelf elementalelf
item.description:
@elementalelf wrote:

ok, i have a major exam in 33 hours that i have done almost no study for, hell, i have never even read the book “othello”, although i was present when it was being studied in class, and i did study alot of it, so i grasp all the basic concepts being brought across:
-othello is a black man in white mans society
-othello only attained his present position because of military superiority
-venetians viewed othello as being primal and “below” them in a sense.
-the thinly shrouded veil of othello’s equality with the venetians is ripped away when he marries desdamona.
-othello is too trusting of others
-Othello descends into madness from iago’s baiting

and i also have watched the movie O plenty of times:
-odin is a black kid at an all white school
-odin only attained his present position because of his sporting prowess
-white people view othello as being “different”
-the dean gets pissed at odin for gettin wiv his daughta(sorry for this line, but i cant think of any other way of putting it. in contrast to othello, the rest of the community still accepts him)
-odin trusts hugo too much
-odin descends into madness from hugo’s baiting. the cocaine doesnt help either.

basically, what im after is as much information as possible that someone can give me about the relationships between the 2 texts when it comes to “text and context”
im really after a band 6(i think its the equivalent of a GPA of 4.0) which is basically the highest mark possible.
according to the board of studies website, to attain a band 6, one must:

· displays a highly developed ability to describe and analyse a broad range of language forms,
features and structures of texts and explain the ways these shape meaning and influence
responses in a variety of texts and contexts.
· presents a critical, refined personal response showing highly developed skills in
interpretation, analysis, synthesis and evaluation of texts and textual detail.
· exhibits an ability to compose imaginatively, interpretively and critically with sustained
precision, flair, originality and sophistication for a variety of audiences, purposes and
contexts in order to explore and communicate ideas, information and values.

http://www.boardofstudies.nsw.edu.au/syllabus_hsc/pdf_doc/english_syl.pdf
around page 45 is the stuff i gotta worry about. im advanced english.
